Introduction.event: Tips on how to use the Timeline
Includes over 600 links to articles from World History Encyclopedia plus you can easily add your own.

Help.event: Using the World History Timeline
A.  GENERAL INFORMATION & DATES
A.1 - About the World History Timeline

Originally just a timeline of Roman Emperors, this was expanded to include some important historical landmarks of ancient Roman Civilisation. Then, given the close ties with ancient Greece, an ancient Greek timeline was added.

Apart from this, there was no grand plan for its expansion; all other categories merely reflecting some of the interests of the creator.

With more than 19,000 unique entries in 33 main categories and over 300 sub-categories, with 3,500+ accompanying comments and over 600 links to articles from the World History Encyclopedia, there's much to explore.

Additionally, there are over 450 entries in 8 Summary Timelines and a Family Tree of the Julio-Claudian Roman Emperors.

Throughout the supporting documentation, the World History Timeline will also be referred to using the acronym WHT.
A.2 - Selection of Entries

The WHT was initially based on the two great Mediterranean civilisations of Greece and Rome and the predominant Western religion, that being Christianity. There are still some regions of the world that are given only partial treatment in the WHT, and this will be progressively addressed in future versions.

Even in those civilisations and time periods that are 'entry rich', there are obviously large gaps. For instance, some lists of rulers are only partial, including only the most historically significant individuals.
A.3 - Period Covered by the WHT

The WHT spans the years 3,400 BC to AD 2,000 although there are numerous references to periods earlier than the 34th century BC. Dates before the 1st millenium BC can be highly speculative with different historians and researchers varying amongst themselves considerably.
Each column represents a 2 year period, although in some instances, such as the Crisis of the Third Century in the Roman Empire, columns can represent 1 year intervals.
A.4 - Dates in the WHT

Other than in row 4 where the year labels appear in the WHT, individual entries only rarely include dates, like year of birth and death for instance. This is useful in reducing visual clutter, particularly in 'entry rich' sections, thereby enhancing readability.

The exception to this is when precise dates are not known with certainty. This is often the case the further back in time we go. In this case, dates will be given in brackets after the entry indicating a century as the start and/or end date rather than a precise year.

Most entries will be accurate to the year, or in some cases a 2-year period.

If any inaccuracies are detected, the compiler of the WHT is happy to correct these and include corrections in future versions.
A.5 - BC/AD vs BCE/CE

The WHT uses the BC/AD system of referring to dates. Many historians prefer the BCE/CE system. Both have their merits. The choice merely reflects familiarity with (and continued use of) the dating system that the compiler of the timeline was taught in his early years.
Some Anomalies
A.6.1 - Monarchs of the British Isles and France & Holy Roman Emperors

The section on the UK and Ireland includes British monarchs from 1066 to the present, and all the West Saxon kings preceding this date.
The section on France includes French monarchs from the Merovinians through to the end of the Monarchy.
The section on Spain includes rulers from the Visigoths onwards.
This data is repeated in the European Monarchies section so that, at a glance, it is easy to see who was on the throne in various kingdoms at the same time.

The section on Rome includes the Holy Roman Emperors as rulers of significant parts of Italy. These also appear in the section on Germany.
A.6.2 - Inclusion of Panama in South America

The division between North and South America is unclear, generally viewed as lying somewhere in the Isthmus of Panama, however, the whole of Panama is considered to be part of North America as its southernmost nation.

Its inclusion in the South America section is due to it being historically part of the Spanish controlled Viceroyalty of Peru.
A.7 - Data Source

A number of sources have been used in the compilation of the WHT but by far the most used is Wikipedia. This has been invaluable, particularly for the many lists of rulers and many of the general entries. We donate a percentage of our profits to the Wikimedia Foundation Inc.
B.1 - Table of Contents (TOC)

The Table of Contents (TOC Tab) lists all 33 major sections of the WHT along with their contents.

The names of the Major Sections are clickable and will take you to the beginning (i.e. 3,400 BC) of each section. The horizontal scroll bar can then be used to move across the section you have chosen.

This is a useful way of moving quickly between sections that can be a large distance from eachother physically.
B.2 - Horizontal Scrolling

To scroll horizontally across the timeline, hold the Ctrl and Shift keys down on the keyboard while scrolling with your mouse wheel. Using this method can give you much smoother horizontal scrolling than with the horizontal scroll bar alone.
B.3 - Quick navigation across long periods of time

To move quicky through the centuries, the horizontal scroll bar can be used, although navigating the WHT with this technique, does not give the same precision as with the Ctrl + Shift + Mouse Wheel method.
B.4 - To go to a specific century
1. Highlight ROW 4 (this limits the search to only the year labels).
2. Press the keyboard shortcut Ctrl + F (MAC: Cmd + F).
3. Type the number for the century you are interested in.
4. Press the Find Next button.
5. Press the Find Next button again to switch between BC and AD dates.
B.5 - To go to the Top or Bottom of the World History Timeline
Located in the top lefthand corner of the WHT, are two arrows which, when clicked, will take you to the top or bottom of the timeline.
Navigation Arrows:
B.6 - Entries spanning many centuries

Numerous entries in the WHT span many centuries. This is particularly the case for long-lasting kingdoms or empires.

For example, the North African Kingdom of Kush (1070 BC–350 AD) spans a period of over 1,000 years, which is equivalent to about 70cm.*

Many monitors would not be wide enough (at 100% zoom level) to show both the start and end dates together on the one screen. In such cases, the WHT includes the name of the entry at the start and end of the coloured bar representing the span of history.
It is possible to simply scroll to the left or right to find the start or end of the entry, but there is a more efficient way to do this.
1. Click anywhere along the coloured bar of the entry (this can also be at the very start or end).

2. Hold down the Ctrl key on the keyboard then press the left or right arrow key depending on whether you
    want to go to the start or end of the entry.

(The keyboard combination is the same for PC and MAC)
You will then be taken to the beginning or end of the entry.
* Assuming a monitor resolution of 1920x1080.
B.7 - Time Slice Viewing
To view a particular time period in order to see contemporary events and people across the entire WHT, you can select and highlight multiple columns.
To select multiple columns:
1. Position the mouse over the middle of the column heading until the mouse pointer changes to a down-pointing arrow.

2. Hold the left mouse button on the column heading and drag across to include all the columns of the time period under consideration. This will highlight in grey, all the entries in the selected columns.
3. Then, with the columns selected, use the vertical scrollbar or mouse wheel to move vertically through the timeline.
4. To deselect the columns, click anwhere outside the highlighted columns.
Increasing or decreasing the column width by mistake

If the mouse is dragged while the mouse pointer appears as a left and right pointing arrow (see example at right), rather than the down-pointing arrow, the column width will be increased or decreased. If this occurs, click anwhere on the WHT, then click the undo button or press Ctrl + Z. (MAC: Cmd + Z).
C.1 - Major Sections of the WHT

The heading names of the 33 major sections are displayed in columns B through O. This part of the timeline remains visible as you scroll through the centuries.

Every section includes a key, listing the sub-sections. An example is given to the right showing part of the key for the section on Rome.
C.2 - Subsections

The major sections of the WHT are sub-divided into subsections, and many of these subsections are grouped together in rows.

These are often indicated by a subsection heading contained within a shaded box with dashed lines. Two examples are given here:
Example 1 - Macedonian Kings.
The list of rulers of the Macedonian Kingdom in the Greece section at 800 BC.
Example 2 - Forum Romanum.
The list of monuments in the Roman Forum in the Ancient Rome section at 750 BC.

Subsection headings can also appear in the area where the major section names appear (columns B to O).

An example is given to the right showing some of the subsections in the Art, Literature, Language & Music major section.
C.3 - Shortcuts to the Summary Timelines
In addition to the main timeline, there are a further eight Summary Timelines which can be found on the Summary Timelines tab.
● World Empires
Clickable links to the Summary Timelines (displayed as an underlined S) are located in the Major Sections in columns B through O.
From the Summary Timelines tab, you can return to the WHT by clicking on the underlined left arrow buttons.
C.4 - Grouping of Rows

All 33 Sections of the WHT and a number of major subsections are grouped so that sections can be temporarily hidden.

This is indicated by the boxes with + and - signs displayed to the left of the row numbers.

These boxes can be clicked to hide and unhide any number of sections. An example showing the Philosophy section is given to the right.

This can make it easier to view sections that might otherwise be hundreds of rows apart.

For example, if you are looking at the section that contains the Greek civilisation, you may also want to view the section on Philosophy. All the intervening sections can be hidden, to better facilitate study of these two sections together.
C.5 - Extra Information (Comments)

The WHT contains over 3,500 comments in addition to the more than 19,000 timeline entries. If an entry has an associated comment, this is indicated by a small red triangle in the upper right area of the cell (like the one you can see in the upper right corner of these instructions). To see the contents of the comment, simply hover the mouse over the cell with the red triangle.
Comments in columns A to O may not appear to display correctly - you need to have scrolled all the way to the left of the timeline (to the year 3,400 BC) to see them.
C.6 - Issue with Comments

There is a known issue with Microsoft Excel where comments are not always displayed correctly. They are often collapsed into a thin horizontal line rather than a correctly-sized yellow text box. Comments may also display a lot of blank space below the text.
The WHT contains a macro to fix this 'on the fly'.

To adjust the height of a comment that is not displaying correctly:

1. Select the cell with the comment by clicking once on the entry.

2. Use the keyboard shortcut shown at right:
The comment will now display with the correct height and width to accommodate the full text of the comment.

Manually adjusting comments:
If you have not enabled macros, comments can still be adjusted manually by following these steps:

1. Right-click the cell containing the comment.

2. Select 'Edit Note' from the pop-up menu.

3. Manually adjust the comment box by dragging the handle to accomodate the text of the comment.

Please note: when manually adjusting a comment, Excel may place the comment box very far away. You will need to scroll up or down to find the comment box before adjusting its size. The macro overcomes this as explained above.
C.7 - Links to Articles

In addition to the 19,000+ entries and 3,500+ Info Boxes there are over 600 links to articles giving more indepth information about selected entries in the
World History Timeline.
These links are indicated by an ì icon next to an entry. Clicking on this icon will take you to the related article on one of the websites listed below.
Websites for Article Links
Website
World History Encyclopedia
Wikipedia

While we have no formal association or financial arrangement with either World History Encyclopedia or Wikipedia, we are very pleased to be able to link to articles on these websites given the quality of the research and writing that their articles offer.
C.8 - Timeline Dot (.) Links

Dot links are hyperlinked subsections of the WHT with links to a group of other related topics or people. These are indicated by a dot (.) or period, placed next to an entry in the timeline. (See list of dot links below.)
To use this feature:
1. Select the cell with the dot (.) next to the entry by clicking or tapping once on the dot.
2. Use the Trace Dependents function (see below for instructions) to show lines that connect to related topics or people.
3. Double-click the blue lines to go to distant links.
Alternatively, use the keyboard shortcut Ctrl + ] to go to distant links, then use the Tab key to move through all the links.
4. Click the Remove Arrows button (see below) to remove the blue arrows from the timeline.
C.9 - The Trace Dependents function

The Trace Dependents function is located on the Ribbon in the Formulas tab. The keyboard shortcut is Alt-M-D.
On a MAC, choose: Formulas tab > Formulas Auditing > Trace Dependents.
This can also be added to the Quick Access Toolbar by right-clicking Trace Dependents and choosing Add to Quick Access Toolbar in the pop-up menu that appears.
C.10 - List of dot-linked subjects in the WHT

Clicking the arrows below will take you to the dot link on the WHT. Sometimes, the destination cell will not be obvious. The destination cell that the hyperlink points to may appear at the far-right or left, or at the top or bottom of your display. Use the keyboard arrow keys to locate the cell.
● Philosophers
List of Ancient Greek Philosophical Schools
● House of Wisdom
C.11 - Adding your own entries

The World History Timeline is not locked down or password protected so it can easily be personalised with the addition of your own new entries. This is a very enjoyable way to use the Timeline. If you plan to make substantial additions (such as an entirely new sub-section), I would recommend using the New Entry Template.
You can download a free copy of this file from our website:

The main benefit of this is to preserve a copy of your entries which will then not be lost if you choose to upgrade to future official versions of the WHT. Your new entries can then be easily transferred to the latest official version.

Full instructions are given in the New Entry Template file.
D.1 - Using the World History Timeline on different devices
The WHT is designed to be viewed on the screen of a PC/Mac or laptop, or tablet device.
At over 24 ft (7m) long and 34 ft (10.5m) high, the physical size of the WHT means it is impractical to view on a phone or small tablet.
To access all features, Microsoft Excel (preferable) or an Excel reader app would also need to be installed on your device.
A free alternative to MS Excel is Libre Office available for both PC and Mac computers.
The WHT was created on a PC but will display the same on a Mac assuming all appropriate fonts are installed on your system (see below for the list of fonts used in the WHT).
D.2 - Fonts used in the WHT
The fonts listed below are used in the WHT. For the data to display correctly, these will need to be installed on your system.
Arial
Calibri
Wingdings
Symbol
Segoe UI Symbol
Tahoma

Timeline.event:
(zẖȝ n mdw-nṯr)
"writing of the words of god"
c. 1600 BC - The chariot is introduced
← 7000–4500 Neolithic villages emerge in the Levant and Iran; domestication of grains, cattle, sheep, and goats
← c. 4000 BC Earliest evidence of human settlement in the area of the city of Sidon
← c. 4000 BC - c. 3000 BC Trade contact between Byblos and Egypt
Hattušiliš I (1650–1620 BC) founds Hittite capital of Hattušaš; Hittite expansion into Kizzuwadna (Cilicia) and Syria
← 3500–3100 Cities and cuneiform writing in Sumer; Sumerian merchants active across the Near East; Transmission of urban civilization from Sumer to Near East
Kingdom of Moab (c. 13th century BC – c. 400 BC)
Kingdom of Ammon (c. 10th century BC – 332 BC)
Qedarite Confederation (9th century BC–1st century BC)
← Choirokoitia Settlement c. 7,000 BC - c. 4,000 BC
Hayasa-Azzi (16th century BC – 13th century BC) - dates uncertain
← Chalcolithic culture of Nakhchivan (c. 4945 - c. 3800 BC)
Colchian culture (2700 BC to 700 BC) - Proto-Colchian (2700–1600 BC)
Kingdom of Thamud - 8th century BC – 5th century AD) (North-West)
Lihyanite Kingdom c. 6th cent BC - c. 3rd cent BC) (North-West)
Salihids (c. 4th cent AD - c. 6th cent AD)
Persian rule (Achaemenid Empire) of Bahrain (6th - 4th centuries BC)
Ayyubid Sultanate of Egypt (East and South Arabia)
Kingdom of Hadhramaut (early 1st millennium BC - c. 290 AD)
Qataban (early 1st millennium BC - late 1st or late 2nd century AD)
Kingdom of Awsan (c. 8th century BC – c. 7th century BC)
← 13,000BC – 9000BC – Neolithic hunters domesticate pig and berries in eastern Anatolia
← c. 10,000 BC – A temple erected at Göbekli Tepe is the oldest known human-made structure in the world
← 7500 BC – 5700 BC – The large Neolithic and Chalcolithic (Copper Age) settlement of Çatalhöyük is inhabited
← 7000 BC – 4500 BC – Neolithic villages emerge in Anatolia; domestication of grains, cattle, sheep, and goats
← 4500BC – 3500 BC – Chalcolithic Age: metallurgy and ceramics in Anatolian villages
The Hittites invade the region of the Hatti and begin a systematic campaign against them
Under the Hittite Warrior-King Hattusili, campaigns are carried to completion subjugating the Hatti who are assimilated into the Hittite culture
Assyrian merchant colonies in eastern Asia Minor
Hittites under Mursilli I sack Babylon, ending Amorite rule
Phrygians invade Anatolia and destroy the Hittite Empire
Saka (9th century BC to 5th century AD)
Kangju Kingdom (1st century BC? - 5th century AD)
The Oxus Civilization is also known as the Bactria–Margiana Archaeological Complex (BMAC)
Bhutan was founded and unified as a country by Ngawang Namgyal (mid 17th century)
Shabdrung Ngawang Namgyal builds Simtokha Dzong at the entrance to Thimphu valley
The first foreign tourists are allowed to enter Bhutan
← c. 9,000 BC Early Neolithic culture with first confirmed semi-permanent settlements in the Bhimbetka rock shelters in modern Madhya Pradesh, India

c. 2800 BC The Indus Valley Civilization expands across the whole of modern-day Pakistan, much of northern India, and large parts of Afghanistan, with Harappa and Mohenjo-daro becoming large metropolises
Persian rule in the northwest ends after Darius III is defeated by Alexander the Great, who establishes the Macedonian Empire after inheriting the Persian Achaemenid Empire
Pakudha Kaccayana - flourished c. 6th century BC
Varāhamihira writes the Pañcasiddhāntikā, a treatise on mathematical astronomy which summarises five earlier astronomical treatises by five authors
Jalal-ud-din Khilji, founder of Khiliji Dynasty
Bhāskara II writes the Siddhānta Shiromani
Marathas defeat the Bijapur Sultanate at the Siege of Ponda
Sambhaji becomes 2nd Chhatrapati of the Maratha Kingdom
Marathas under Sambhaji defeat the Mughal Army in the Battle of Wai
The Sikandara was plundered by Rajaram Jat
Sambhaji is ambushed, tortured and killed by the Mughals for refusing to convert to Islam
Rajaram I becomes the third Chhatrapati of the Maratha Kingdom
Maratha Kingdom defeats the Mughal Empire in the Battle of Athani
Mughal army suffer multiple defeats against the Marathas
Sikhs under Guru Gobind Singh defeat Mughal forces in the Battle of Guler
Guru Gobind Singh (10th Sikh Guru) creates Khalsa, the saint-soldier at Anandpur Sahib, Punjab
Sikhs defeat Mughals in the Battle of Anandpur
Sikhs defeat Mughals in the Battle of Nirmohgarh
Death of Mughal emperor Aurangzeb marks the end of Mughal territorial expansion over India
Guru Gobind Singh is assassinated by Mughals - the Guru Granth Sahib becomes the eternal Sikh Guru
Meitei king Pamheipa (Gharib Nawaz) introduces Hinduism as the state religion and changes the name of the kingdom to Manipur
Bajirao I appointed by Shahu as Peshwa
Meitei king Gharib Nawaz invades Burma
Marathas defeat the Mughal Empire in the Battle of Palkhed
Marathas defeat the Mughal Empire in the Battle of Bundelkhand
Marathas defeat the Mughal Empire in the Battle of Dabhoi
Marathas win the Battle of Bhopal
Marathas defeat the Mughal Empire in the Battle of Delhi
Marathas under Bajirao I defeat the Portuguese in the Battle of Vasai
Nader Shah invades India from Iran, capturing and sacking Delhi
The island of Labuan is ceded to Britain
Expantion of Khmer influence to the Chao Phraya valley
The royal Khmer court moves to Longvek
Proposed military alliance between Hue and Cambodia
Vietnamese refugees permitted to settle in the Khmer sea port of Prey Nokor
Cambodia brakes relations with the Socialist Republic of Vietnam
The last Vietnamese troops withdraw from Cambodia
A group of Dominican friars established the village of Lifau.
The capital was moved to Dili
The Portuguese and Dutch agree to a formal division of the island
c. 8th to 10th centuries - According to linguistic and other historical evidence, Tai-speaking tribes migrated southwestward to the modern territories of Laos and Thailand from Guangxi
Fa Ngum establishes the Lan Xang kingdom
Earliest mention of the Melayu Kingdom

entry.event: A.6.2 - Inclusion of Panama in South America

searchable_text.text:
None The division between North and South America is unclear, generally viewed as lying somewhere in the Isthmus of Panama, however, the whole of Panama is considered to be part of North America as its southernmost nation.

Its inclusion in the South America section is due to it being historically part of the Spanish controlled Viceroyalty of Peru.

This is a useful way of moving quickly between sections that can be a large distance from eachother physically.

entry.event:
The Table of Contents (TOC Tab) lists all 33 major sections of the WHT along with their contents.

The names of the Major Sections are clickable and will take you to the beginning (i.e. 3,400 BC) of each section. The horizontal scroll bar can then be used to move across the section you have chosen.

This is a useful way of moving quickly between sections that can be a large distance from eachother physically.

searchable_text.text: None To scroll horizontally across the timeline, hold the Ctrl and Shift keys down on the keyboard while scrolling with your mouse wheel. Using this method can give you much smoother horizontal scrolling than with the horizontal scroll bar alone.

entry.event: To scroll horizontally across the timeline, hold the Ctrl and Shift keys down on the keyboard while scrolling with your mouse wheel. Using this method can give you much smoother horizontal scrolling than with the horizontal scroll bar alone.

searchable_text.text: None B.3 - Quick navigation across long periods of time

entry.event: B.3 - Quick navigation across long periods of time

searchable_text.text: None To move quicky through the centuries, the horizontal scroll bar can be used, although navigating the WHT with this technique, does not give the same precision as with the Ctrl + Shift + Mouse Wheel method.

entry.event: To move quicky through the centuries, the horizontal scroll bar can be used, although navigating the WHT with this technique, does not give the same precision as with the Ctrl + Shift + Mouse Wheel method.

searchable_text.text: None B.4 - To go to a specific century

entry.event: B.4 - To go to a specific century

searchable_text.text: None 1. Highlight ROW 4 (this limits the search to only the year labels).

entry.event: 1. Highlight ROW 4 (this limits the search to only the year labels).

searchable_text.text: None 2. Press the keyboard shortcut Ctrl + F (MAC: Cmd + F).

entry.event: 2. Press the keyboard shortcut Ctrl + F (MAC: Cmd + F).

searchable_text.text: None 3. Type the number for the century you are interested in.

entry.event: 3. Type the number for the century you are interested in.

searchable_text.text: None 4. Press the Find Next button.
None 5. Press the Find Next button again to switch between BC and AD dates.

entry.event: 5. Press the Find Next button again to switch between BC and AD dates.

searchable_text.text: None B.5 - To go to the Top or Bottom of the World History Timeline

entry.event: B.5 - To go to the Top or Bottom of the World History Timeline

searchable_text.text: None Located in the top lefthand corner of the WHT, are two arrows which, when clicked, will take you to the top or bottom of the timeline.

entry.event: Located in the top lefthand corner of the WHT, are two arrows which, when clicked, will take you to the top or bottom of the timeline.

searchable_text.text: None B.6 - Entries spanning many centuries

None Numerous entries in the WHT span many centuries. This is particularly the case for long-lasting kingdoms or empires.

For example, the North African Kingdom of Kush (1070 BC–350 AD) spans a period of over 1,000 years, which is equivalent to about 70cm.*

entry.event:
Numerous entries in the WHT span many centuries. This is particularly the case for long-lasting kingdoms or empires.

For example, the North African Kingdom of Kush (1070 BC–350 AD) spans a period of over 1,000 years, which is equivalent to about 70cm.*

searchable_text.text: None Many monitors would not be wide enough (at 100% zoom level) to show both the start and end dates together on the one screen. In such cases, the WHT includes the name of the entry at the start and end of the coloured bar representing the span of history.

entry.event: Many monitors would not be wide enough (at 100% zoom level) to show both the start and end dates together on the one screen. In such cases, the WHT includes the name of the entry at the start and end of the coloured bar representing the span of history.

searchable_text.text: None It is possible to simply scroll to the left or right to find the start or end of the entry, but there is a more efficient way to do this.

entry.event: It is possible to simply scroll to the left or right to find the start or end of the entry, but there is a more efficient way to do this.

searchable_text.text: None 1. Click anywhere along the coloured bar of the entry (this can also be at the very start or end).

entry.event: 1. Click anywhere along the coloured bar of the entry (this can also be at the very start or end).

searchable_text.text:
None 2. Hold down the Ctrl key on the keyboard then press the left or right arrow key depending on whether you
    want to go to the start or end of the entry.

(The keyboard combination is the same for PC and MAC)

entry.event:
2. Hold down the Ctrl key on the keyboard then press the left or right arrow key depending on whether you
    want to go to the start or end of the entry.

(The keyboard combination is the same for PC and MAC)

searchable_text.text: None You will then be taken to the beginning or end of the entry.

entry.event: You will then be taken to the beginning or end of the entry.

searchable_text.text: None * Assuming a monitor resolution of 1920x1080.
None To view a particular time period in order to see contemporary events and people across the entire WHT, you can select and highlight multiple columns.

entry.event: To view a particular time period in order to see contemporary events and people across the entire WHT, you can select and highlight multiple columns.

searchable_text.text: None 1. Position the mouse over the middle of the column heading until the mouse pointer changes to a down-pointing arrow.

entry.event: 1. Position the mouse over the middle of the column heading until the mouse pointer changes to a down-pointing arrow.

searchable_text.text: None 2. Hold the left mouse button on the column heading and drag across to include all the columns of the time period under consideration. This will highlight in grey, all the entries in the selected columns.

entry.event: 2. Hold the left mouse button on the column heading and drag across to include all the columns of the time period under consideration. This will highlight in grey, all the entries in the selected columns.

searchable_text.text: None 3. Then, with the columns selected, use the vertical scrollbar or mouse wheel to move vertically through the timeline.

entry.event: 3. Then, with the columns selected, use the vertical scrollbar or mouse wheel to move vertically through the timeline.

searchable_text.text: None 4. To deselect the columns, click anwhere outside the highlighted columns.

entry.event: 4. To deselect the columns, click anwhere outside the highlighted columns.

searchable_text.text: None Increasing or decreasing the column width by mistake

entry.event: Increasing or decreasing the column width by mistake

searchable_text.text: None If the mouse is dragged while the mouse pointer appears as a left and right pointing arrow (see example at right), rather than the down-pointing arrow, the column width will be increased or decreased. If this occurs, click anwhere on the WHT, then click the undo button or press Ctrl + Z. (MAC: Cmd + Z).

entry.event: If the mouse is dragged while the mouse pointer appears as a left and right pointing arrow (see example at right), rather than the down-pointing arrow, the column width will be increased or decreased. If this occurs, click anwhere on the WHT, then click the undo button or press Ctrl + Z. (MAC: Cmd + Z).

searchable_text.text: None C.1 - Major Sections of the WHT

entry.event: C.1 - Major Sections of the WHT

searchable_text.text:
None The heading names of the 33 major sections are displayed in columns B through O. This part of the timeline remains visible as you scroll through the centuries.

Every section includes a key, listing the sub-sections. An example is given to the right showing part of the key for the section on Rome.

entry.event:
The heading names of the 33 major sections are displayed in columns B through O. This part of the timeline remains visible as you scroll through the centuries.

Every section includes a key, listing the sub-sections. An example is given to the right showing part of the key for the section on Rome.

searchable_text.text:
None The major sections of the WHT are sub-divided into subsections, and many of these subsections are grouped together in rows.

These are often indicated by a subsection heading contained within a shaded box with dashed lines. Two examples are given here:

entry.event:
The major sections of the WHT are sub-divided into subsections, and many of these subsections are grouped together in rows.

These are often indicated by a subsection heading contained within a shaded box with dashed lines. Two examples are given here:

searchable_text.text: None The list of rulers of the Macedonian Kingdom in the Greece section at 800 BC.

entry.event: The list of rulers of the Macedonian Kingdom in the Greece section at 800 BC.

searchable_text.text: None The list of monuments in the Roman Forum in the Ancient Rome section at 750 BC.

entry.event: The list of monuments in the Roman Forum in the Ancient Rome section at 750 BC.

searchable_text.text:
None Subsection headings can also appear in the area where the major section names appear (columns B to O).

An example is given to the right showing some of the subsections in the Art, Literature, Language & Music major section.

entry.event:
Subsection headings can also appear in the area where the major section names appear (columns B to O).

An example is given to the right showing some of the subsections in the Art, Literature, Language & Music major section.

searchable_text.text: None C.3 - Shortcuts to the Summary Timelines

entry.event: C.3 - Shortcuts to the Summary Timelines

searchable_text.text: None In addition to the main timeline, there are a further eight Summary Timelines which can be found on the Summary Timelines tab.

entry.event: In addition to the main timeline, there are a further eight Summary Timelines which can be found on the Summary Timelines tab.

searchable_text.text: None Clickable links to the Summary Timelines (displayed as an underlined S) are located in the Major Sections in columns B through O.

entry.event: Clickable links to the Summary Timelines (displayed as an underlined S) are located in the Major Sections in columns B through O.

searchable_text.text: None From the Summary Timelines tab, you can return to the WHT by clicking on the underlined left arrow buttons.

entry.event: From the Summary Timelines tab, you can return to the WHT by clicking on the underlined left arrow buttons.

searchable_text.text:
None All 33 Sections of the WHT and a number of major subsections are grouped so that sections can be temporarily hidden.

This is indicated by the boxes with + and - signs displayed to the left of the row numbers.

These boxes can be clicked to hide and unhide any number of sections. An example showing the Philosophy section is given to the right.

This can make it easier to view sections that might otherwise be hundreds of rows apart.

For example, if you are looking at the section that contains the Greek civilisation, you may also want to view the section on Philosophy. All the intervening sections can be hidden, to better facilitate study of these two sections together.

entry.event:
All 33 Sections of the WHT and a number of major subsections are grouped so that sections can be temporarily hidden.

This is indicated by the boxes with + and - signs displayed to the left of the row numbers.

These boxes can be clicked to hide and unhide any number of sections. An example showing the Philosophy section is given to the right.

This can make it easier to view sections that might otherwise be hundreds of rows apart.

For example, if you are looking at the section that contains the Greek civilisation, you may also want to view the section on Philosophy. All the intervening sections can be hidden, to better facilitate study of these two sections together.

searchable_text.text: None The WHT contains over 3,500 comments in addition to the more than 19,000 timeline entries. If an entry has an associated comment, this is indicated by a small red triangle in the upper right area of the cell (like the one you can see in the upper right corner of these instructions). To see the contents of the comment, simply hover the mouse over the cell with the red triangle.

entry.event: The WHT contains over 3,500 comments in addition to the more than 19,000 timeline entries. If an entry has an associated comment, this is indicated by a small red triangle in the upper right area of the cell (like the one you can see in the upper right corner of these instructions). To see the contents of the comment, simply hover the mouse over the cell with the red triangle.

searchable_text.text: None Comments in columns A to O may not appear to display correctly - you need to have scrolled all the way to the left of the timeline (to the year 3,400 BC) to see them.

entry.event: Comments in columns A to O may not appear to display correctly - you need to have scrolled all the way to the left of the timeline (to the year 3,400 BC) to see them.

searchable_text.text: None There is a known issue with Microsoft Excel where comments are not always displayed correctly. They are often collapsed into a thin horizontal line rather than a correctly-sized yellow text box. Comments may also display a lot of blank space below the text.

entry.event: There is a known issue with Microsoft Excel where comments are not always displayed correctly. They are often collapsed into a thin horizontal line rather than a correctly-sized yellow text box. Comments may also display a lot of blank space below the text.

searchable_text.text: None The WHT contains a macro to fix this 'on the fly'.

entry.event: The WHT contains a macro to fix this 'on the fly'.

searchable_text.text:
None To adjust the height of a comment that is not displaying correctly:

1. Select the cell with the comment by clicking once on the entry.

2. Use the keyboard shortcut shown at right:

entry.event:
To adjust the height of a comment that is not displaying correctly:

1. Select the cell with the comment by clicking once on the entry.

2. Use the keyboard shortcut shown at right:

searchable_text.text: None The comment will now display with the correct height and width to accommodate the full text of the comment.

entry.event: The comment will now display with the correct height and width to accommodate the full text of the comment.

searchable_text.text:
None Manually adjusting comments:
If you have not enabled macros, comments can still be adjusted manually by following these steps:

1. Right-click the cell containing the comment.

2. Select 'Edit Note' from the pop-up menu.

3. Manually adjust the comment box by dragging the handle to accomodate the text of the comment.

Please note: when manually adjusting a comment, Excel may place the comment box very far away. You will need to scroll up or down to find the comment box before adjusting its size. The macro overcomes this as explained above.

entry.event:
Manually adjusting comments:
If you have not enabled macros, comments can still be adjusted manually by following these steps:

1. Right-click the cell containing the comment.

2. Select 'Edit Note' from the pop-up menu.

3. Manually adjust the comment box by dragging the handle to accomodate the text of the comment.

Please note: when manually adjusting a comment, Excel may place the comment box very far away. You will need to scroll up or down to find the comment box before adjusting its size. The macro overcomes this as explained above.

searchable_text.text:
None In addition to the 19,000+ entries and 3,500+ Info Boxes there are over 600 links to articles giving more indepth information about selected entries in the
World History Timeline.

entry.event:
In addition to the 19,000+ entries and 3,500+ Info Boxes there are over 600 links to articles giving more indepth information about selected entries in the
World History Timeline.

searchable_text.text: None These links are indicated by an ì icon next to an entry. Clicking on this icon will take you to the related article on one of the websites listed below.

entry.event: These links are indicated by an ì icon next to an entry. Clicking on this icon will take you to the related article on one of the websites listed below.

searchable_text.text: None While we have no formal association or financial arrangement with either World History Encyclopedia or Wikipedia, we are very pleased to be able to link to articles on these websites given the quality of the research and writing that their articles offer.

entry.event: While we have no formal association or financial arrangement with either World History Encyclopedia or Wikipedia, we are very pleased to be able to link to articles on these websites given the quality of the research and writing that their articles offer.

searchable_text.text: None Dot links are hyperlinked subsections of the WHT with links to a group of other related topics or people. These are indicated by a dot (.) or period, placed next to an entry in the timeline. (See list of dot links below.)

entry.event: Dot links are hyperlinked subsections of the WHT with links to a group of other related topics or people. These are indicated by a dot (.) or period, placed next to an entry in the timeline. (See list of dot links below.)

searchable_text.text: None 1. Select the cell with the dot (.) next to the entry by clicking or tapping once on the dot.

entry.event: 1. Select the cell with the dot (.) next to the entry by clicking or tapping once on the dot.

searchable_text.text: None 2. Use the Trace Dependents function (see below for instructions) to show lines that connect to related topics or people.

entry.event: 2. Use the Trace Dependents function (see below for instructions) to show lines that connect to related topics or people.

searchable_text.text: None 3. Double-click the blue lines to go to distant links.

entry.event: 3. Double-click the blue lines to go to distant links.

searchable_text.text: None Alternatively, use the keyboard shortcut Ctrl + ] to go to distant links, then use the Tab key to move through all the links.

entry.event: Alternatively, use the keyboard shortcut Ctrl + ] to go to distant links, then use the Tab key to move through all the links.

searchable_text.text: None 4. Click the Remove Arrows button (see below) to remove the blue arrows from the timeline.

entry.event: 4. Click the Remove Arrows button (see below) to remove the blue arrows from the timeline.

searchable_text.text: None C.9 - The Trace Dependents function

None The Trace Dependents function is located on the Ribbon in the Formulas tab. The keyboard shortcut is Alt-M-D.
On a MAC, choose: Formulas tab > Formulas Auditing > Trace Dependents.

entry.event:
The Trace Dependents function is located on the Ribbon in the Formulas tab. The keyboard shortcut is Alt-M-D.
On a MAC, choose: Formulas tab > Formulas Auditing > Trace Dependents.

searchable_text.text: None C.11 - Adding your own entries

None The World History Timeline is not locked down or password protected so it can easily be personalised with the addition of your own new entries. This is a very enjoyable way to use the Timeline. If you plan to make substantial additions (such as an entirely new sub-section), I would recommend using the New Entry Template.

entry.event: The World History Timeline is not locked down or password protected so it can easily be personalised with the addition of your own new entries. This is a very enjoyable way to use the Timeline. If you plan to make substantial additions (such as an entirely new sub-section), I would recommend using the New Entry Template.

searchable_text.text: None You can download a free copy of this file from our website:

entry.event: You can download a free copy of this file from our website:

searchable_text.text:
None 
The main benefit of this is to preserve a copy of your entries which will then not be lost if you choose to upgrade to future official versions of the WHT. Your new entries can then be easily transferred to the latest official version.

Full instructions are given in the New Entry Template file.

entry.event:
The main benefit of this is to preserve a copy of your entries which will then not be lost if you choose to upgrade to future official versions of the WHT. Your new entries can then be easily transferred to the latest official version.

Full instructions are given in the New Entry Template file.
